description:
Added a frontend to read gadget simulations run with the Eagle chemistry network. It's really similar to the OWLS frontend and as such inherits a lot of the classes, but loads ion densities written out by the simulation rather than using Cloudy tables to interpret them. 

I have a test dataset I can send out, but I'm still waiting on permission to put it on the hub.
title: Eagle Frontend

content.raw: @galtay want to give this a look?
content.html: Gabriel Altay want to give this a look?

content.raw: I think this line should be deleted.
content.html: I think this line should be deleted.

content.raw: Do you think it might be simpler to inherit from `OWLSDataset`?  That should hopefully reduce the amount of copy/paste below.
content.html: Do you think it might be simpler to inherit from OWLSDataset? That should hopefully reduce the amount of copy/paste below.

content.raw: What type of particle do these two correspond to?  Can they get nicer names?
content.html: What type of particle do these two correspond to? Can they get nicer names?

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1248/
content.html: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1248/

content.raw: Yeah I felt like it was a ton of copy paste, but I wasn't sure how to handle that one line was different? Should I just put the current_time finding outside of that function? Or have some parameter that gives the name that should be used to look up the time with?
content.html: Yeah I felt like it was a ton of copy paste, but I wasn't sure how to handle that one line was different? Should I just put the current_time finding outside of that function? Or have some parameter that gives the name that should be used to look up the time with?

content.raw: Yeah, I was just told these were also dark matter particles, but just bigger ones for the zoom. So I thought giving it the name dm as well would mess things up, and that dm_2, dm_3 were not any more informative. I think I need a gadget expert here!
content.html: Yeah, I was just told these were also dark matter particles, but just bigger ones for the zoom. So I thought giving it the name dm as well would mess things up, and that dm_2, dm_3 were not any more informative. I think I need a gadget expert here!

content.raw: In my personal I/O codes, I usually create a variable that holds the name of the parameter and set it based on the I/O type. Something like Time_Gyr_HDF5_Name
content.html: In my personal I/O codes, I usually create a variable that holds the name of the parameter and set it based on the I/O type. Something like Time_Gyr_HDF5_Name

content.raw: The standard Eagle runs will only have particle types 0,1,4,5.  Hillary is correct, the other two particle types are *usually* used for course dark matter particles in zoom runs.  BUT this is a convention and not a hard rule.  I've haven't seen any of the zoom runs for Eagle yet so am not sure exactly what the format will be.  For now, I think what Hillary put is fine b/c 1) there wont be any PartType2 or PartType3 in the "standard" Eagle runs and 2) We can update when we know exactly what the zoom run format is.
content.html: The standard Eagle runs will only have particle types 0,1,4,5. Hillary is correct, the other two particle types are usually used for course dark matter particles in zoom runs. BUT this is a convention and not a hard rule. I've haven't seen any of the zoom runs for Eagle yet so am not sure exactly what the format will be. For now, I think what Hillary put is fine b/c 1) there wont be any PartType2 or PartType3 in the "standard" Eagle runs and 2) We can update when we know exactly what the zoom run format is.

content.raw: I sent an email request to the Eagle folks asking again about putting a low resolution snapshot on the yt data hub to hopefuly move things along.
content.html: I sent an email request to the Eagle folks asking again about putting a low resolution snapshot on the yt data hub to hopefuly move things along.

content.raw: The other thing is it would be really nice to use the HashTable data for "region" readins, but that can be added later.
content.html: The other thing is it would be really nice to use the HashTable data for "region" readins, but that can be added later.

content.raw: Hillary, where did you get the ion densities?  I don't see them in the snapshots.  Maybe I'm looking at a different version of output than you?
content.html: Hillary, where did you get the ion densities? I don't see them in the snapshots. Maybe I'm looking at a different version of output than you?

content.raw:
Hm in my outputs there is a table under PartType0/ChemistryAbundances that
contains all the ion information in 157xnumber of particles element array.
I'm not sure exactly what version it is that I've got outputs from, but
maybe it would be helpful if I emailed you and Ben Oppenheimer (who I've
been working with on this) off list?
content.html: Hm in my outputs there is a table under PartType0/ChemistryAbundances that contains all the ion information in 157xnumber of particles element array. I'm not sure exactly what version it is that I've got outputs from, but maybe it would be helpful if I emailed you and Ben Oppenheimer (who I've been working with on this) off list?

content.raw: Sounds good, but if the ions are an extension due to Oppenheimer it may be confusing to have them in the general Eagle front end.
content.html: Sounds good, but if the ions are an extension due to Oppenheimer it may be confusing to have them in the general Eagle front end.

content.raw: Be careful here, I think you need a factor of 1/h.   All the lengths in the snapshots are in units of comoving Mpc/h. For example, in the Eagle non-zoom snapshot that will go on the yt data hub, the box is 8.47125 comoving Mpc/h or 12.5 comoving Mpc.
content.html: Be careful here, I think you need a factor of 1/h. All the lengths in the snapshots are in units of comoving Mpc/h. For example, in the Eagle non-zoom snapshot that will go on the yt data hub, the box is 8.47125 comoving Mpc/h or 12.5 comoving Mpc.

content.raw: Hm this is all unchanged from the OWLSDataset class. Is there a problem with those?
content.html: Hm this is all unchanged from the OWLSDataset class. Is there a problem with those?

content.raw: Oh :) If it comes out right it comes out right.  Perhaps the factor of h is being taken care of somewhere else.  We should just remember to double check that the boxsizes come out right on some of the test data.  I'll work on putting together an example notebook this week for OWLS and non-zoom Eagle.
content.html: Oh :) If it comes out right it comes out right. Perhaps the factor of h is being taken care of somewhere else. We should just remember to double check that the boxsizes come out right on some of the test data. I'll work on putting together an example notebook this week for OWLS and non-zoom Eagle.

content.raw: ps, just checked the OWLS I/O and a slice plot does produce the correct units for box width.
content.html: ps, just checked the OWLS I/O and a slice plot does produce the correct units for box width.

content.raw: Hi all, this is really good.  I'd like a chance to review it and see if we can consolidate some code before it goes in.  Does that sound okay?
content.html: Hi all, this is really good. I'd like a chance to review it and see if we can consolidate some code before it goes in. Does that sound okay?

content.raw: Just to move in some stuff from an offline email thread Hillary and I have been having ... we need a flag that specifies where yt should get ion abundnace information.  some of the Eagle snapshots (e.g. the zoom runs) will have this information in the snapshot, others (e.g. the non-zoom runs) will need to interpolate from tables as in the OWLS I/O.
content.html: Just to move in some stuff from an offline email thread Hillary and I have been having ... we need a flag that specifies where yt should get ion abundnace information. some of the Eagle snapshots (e.g. the zoom runs) will have this information in the snapshot, others (e.g. the non-zoom runs) will need to interpolate from tables as in the OWLS I/O.

content.raw:
yep! Im going to submit a bunch of changes based on the suggestions Ive
already got in the next day or two though, so you might want to hold off
looking until then.
content.html: yep! Im going to submit a bunch of changes based on the suggestions Ive already got in the next day or two though, so you might want to hold off looking until then.

content.raw: Could that be auto-detected?
content.html: Could that be auto-detected?

content.raw: Yes.  A small hickup is that the naming conventions for the ion abundances are slightly different in different types of output (could check for the existence of both though).  This could make it difficult for people to use the interpolated values if the snapshot values existed but that would be a rare use case.  Maybe this order of of checking 1) are the ion abundances in the snapshot then return those  2) if not in snapshot do we have access to an interpolation table if so return those  3) if not in snapshot and no table tell user they have to calculate their own.  As things are, the interpolation table can be downloaded so it will always be there, but I think Joop wasn't thrilled about having the ion abundance table in the public space so he might ask me to take it down.
content.html: Yes. A small hickup is that the naming conventions for the ion abundances are slightly different in different types of output (could check for the existence of both though). This could make it difficult for people to use the interpolated values if the snapshot values existed but that would be a rare use case. Maybe this order of of checking 1) are the ion abundances in the snapshot then return those 2) if not in snapshot do we have access to an interpolation table if so return those 3) if not in snapshot and no table tell user they have to calculate their own. As things are, the interpolation table can be downloaded so it will always be there, but I think Joop wasn't thrilled about having the ion abundance table in the public space so he might ask me to take it down.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: This looks good.
content.html: This looks good.
